Do you plan to log the other link status indicators as well?

hi timothy Vitkin , Since in ncsi-util yosemite 3.5 version only link status field and speed are implemented, we implemented the same in ncsi-netlink yv4 . Shall I address all the fields or any particular fileds of interest? please suggest.
Hi Timothy, Have added other fields in link status as per your suggestion.Please review.

Please resubmit after fixing the CI build issues,

openbmc/phosphor-networkd 
    Formatting code under /data0/jenkins/workspace/ci-repository/openbmc/phosphor-networkd
    markdownlint: cannot find .markdownlint.yaml; using /data0/jenkins/workspace/ci-repository/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts/config/markdownlint.yaml
    prettier: cannot find .prettierrc.yaml; using /data0/jenkins/workspace/ci-repository/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts/config/prettierrc.yaml
    Running commit_gitlint
-: UC1 Line contains hard tab characters (\t): "	ncsi-netlink -x 2 -p 0 -c 0 0xa"
    Running commit_spelling

Hi Johnathan,
Have fixed CI build issues and submitted patch.
Regards,
Surendra A.

What is this??

I don't think anyone wants to remember a bunch of random magic numbers that they insert on the command line.

Hi patrick,
 Taken reference from ncsi-util in yosemite 3.5 which was parsing 0x0a in commandline for link status .Now I have change to use option -l as u suggested.
Regards,
Surendra A.

Absolutely not.  I don't think we want to see a generic "send random bytes out NCSI" tool because that's just going to lead to people elsewhere hardcoding random strings of bytes in scripts and tools.

If you just want to send random strings of bytes, use net-cat (nc).
Done
Should these defines be in the header file. ncsi_util.hpp ?

Hi Tom,These defines are internal/private to file ncsi_util.hpp and will not used anywhere.
Regards.
Resolved comments on command line parsing.Also updated link status structure and accessing completion codes.Kindly review.
Perhaps this is too much for this util.

an effort was made to align the 
help
info
set
clear
description messages

Perhaps all the help text should be aligned to the same level as "Specify device ifindex"?
Alligned description text as suggested.

Consider using a std::array instead?
That way the NULL test below, which needs modification anyway, doesn't need to be done?
Done

Don't pass an unsigned char, and then cast it.
Pass a ptr to the data structure instead.

Make this a 'const' ptr?
Done
Perform all endianess modifications in the getLinkStatusResponse callback.
Done
Done
Done

If you aren't using 'arg' apply the C++ atribute
[[maybe_unused]]
Hi John, After using [[maybe_unused]] we are seeing ncsi-netlink prints link status response and control stucks there.It is not exiting.We are looking into it.
Done

This line is unnecessary in combination with the [[maybe_unused]] attribute.
It also looks suspect because I expect arg to be input data.
Thanks for confirming.
Adjust data for host endianess (ntohl) here before calling print()
If i am using ntohl on length it prints as NCSI Response length : 0x100000 which is invalid ,but with htons it prints as NCSI Response length : 0x10 which is expected.

Why not just make the data structure include the header, and then pass a const ptr to the print function?
Don't bother with the error prone math, and allow the compiler to manage the indexing.
Done

printLinkStatus(static_cast<linkstatus>(ncsiRespHdr));
Perhaps add const to the conversion too.
Done

Remove?
This isn't used anywhere in this commit.
Done
Don't define this here, as it isn't used outside ncsi_util.cpp
Done

Hi Johnathan,
Resolved your comments on structure access,Host endianess etc. Still ned to address comment on [[maybe_used]].Please review.
Regards,
Surendra A.

Hi Timothy,John,Patrick
Resolved all comments.Kindly review and provide feedback.
Some additional observations on the latest commit

You're repeating the pattern that begins on line 175 many times below.
There's many duplicated strings that only differ by a "Yes"/"No" or "Up"/"Down".
The code would consume less vertical space if it followed this pattern:

    lg2::debug("Link Status : Link is {UPDOWN}", "UPDOWN",
               linkstatus.bits.linkFlag ? "Up" : "Down");
Done

Capitalize to match "Not capable"?
i.e. "Capable"
It looks a little weird to have
xyz: capable
zzy: Not capable
Done

Move these definitions and constexprs to ncsi_util.cpp?
Make the constexprs static?
No other module is using these.
Done
nit: this still doesn't match your name in the CLA.
Done

Hi John, 
As suggested reduced vertical space using terinay operator and resolved other comments.Kindly review. Thanks

Thank you for making the requested changes.
I'm going to allow others to supply comments now.
You will need one more +1 before a maintainer will take a look at the code.
Have someone on your team review, and provide feedback.
I could add some comments myself, but I don't want to bikeshed this commit.
Looks good
Adding AndrewJ for best practices on struct unpacking.  It seems like this union approach is quite unsafe.
Are we really cool with doing this?  This seems very compiler and architecture specific.  I'm pretty sure that little endian vs big endian lays out the structure in completely the opposite way.

This really should be avoided. Extraction of fields is best done using a shift-and-mask approach.

From `11.4.9 Bit-fields` (`[class.bit]`) in N4860 ([C++20 draft standard](https://wg21.link/std20)):

> Allocation of bit-fields within a class object is implementation-defined. Alignment of bit-fields is implementation-defined. Bit-fields are packed into some addressable allocation
unit. [Note: Bit-fields straddle allocation units on some machines and not on others. Bit-fields are assigned right-to-left on some machines, left-to-right on others. — end note]

They're not portable and a whole bunch of pain. I really recommend avoiding them (they also have a whole bunch of concurrency problems, but that might not be a concern here).
Done

I have rebased to master.I observed below files which are not used/modified by me are reflecting in OpenBMC CI clang format errors.
src/dhcp_configuration.cpp
src/ethernet_interface.cpp
src/ibm/hypervisor-network-mgr-src/hyp_ethernet_interface.hpp
src/ibm/hypervisor-network-mgr-src/hyp_network_manager.hpp
src/ibm/hypervisor-network-mgr-src/hyp_sys_config.hpp
src/network_manager.cpp
src/ncsi_util.cpp
src/network_manager.cpp
src/rtnetlink_server.cpp
src/system_configuration.cpp
src/system_queries.cpp
test/ibm/hypervisor-network-mgr-test/mock_hyp_sys_config.hpp

I manually fixed up clang-format issues for you after I merged the overall clang-format fixups (which were inducing a bunch of changes in your commit that were unrelated).  There are still outstanding review comments related to struct unpacking that needs to be resolved.

Hi Jeffery and Patrick,
Implemented shift and mask approach as suggested.Kindly review.
Thanks,
Surendra A.
nit: NCSICompletionCodes
Done
nit: Suggest putting these all into a namespace since you've added a lot of free standing variables.
Done

All of these can be derived straight from the mask with e.g. the C++ equivalent of [ffs(3)](https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/ffs.3.html)

This isn't my code, but I would really encourage you to write some helpers for field extraction so this all isn't so brittle.
Done
Unsafe C-style cast onto packed struct.

Hi Patrick,
As suggested updated to c++ style unpacking.Also observed this style of casting/unpacking being is used in multiple places in  phosphorus-networkd repo.
   auto* linkResp =
        static_cast<getLinkStatusResponse*>(nla_data(tb[NCSI_ATTR_DATA]));
Please provide comment on this.
Regards,
Surendra A.

Hi Andrew,
Updated code as per your suggestion.Added helper function to get first set bit position from mask.Kindly review.
Regards,
Surendra A.
Eh? Drop this and use `ffsll()`? Or `__builtin_ffsll()`?
Done

I think something like (not tested at all):

```
std::uint32_t field_get(std::uint32_t value, std::uint32_t mask)
{
    return static_cast<std::uint32_t>((value & mask) >> __builtin_ffsll(mask));
}
```

Then you can turn this into:

```
lg2::debug("Parallel Detection : {USED_NOTUSED}",
           "USED_NOTUSED", field_get(linkRcv->linkStatus, parallelDetectionMask));
```

It's probably worth having a look at how the kernel solves these things:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/tree/include/linux/bitfield.h?h=v6.11-rc5#n145
Done

Hi Andrew,
Updated code as per your suggestion.Updated helper function with __builtin_ffsll .Kindly review.
Regards,
Surendra A.
Looks good
Done
Done
Which capability? Include 1000TFD in the argument name? Same for below.
Done
Done

Similar to my comment on the AEN patch: have you considered how the interacts with the kernel's own NCSI state?

In this case, the GLS link data is already queried by the kernel, and available through the netlink API. Do we actually need to perform our own GLS command here?

Hi Jeremy,
We followed command and response approach to extract reason/response codes, link status and other fields like auto negotiations  as per DSP0222 NCSI Spec 8.4.24.

We are justing using NL APIs(nla_put) for parsing command operation 0x0a 
and receiving the response through NL API via nla_data.

If we just use already query data with out sending command,
We cannot extract response/reason code and fields other than link status.

Command:
    return internal::applyCmd(
        ifindex,
        internal::Command(ncsi_nl_commands::NCSI_CMD_SEND_CMD,
                          ncsiCmdGetLinkStatus),
        package, channel, NONE, internal::linkStatusCallBack);
        
Response:
auto* linkResp =
        static_cast<getLinkStatusResponse*>(nla_data(tb[NCSI_ATTR_DATA]));
        
Please provide your comments on this.

Regards,
Surendra A.

Are the Response and Reason codes at all useful to you though?

I understand that the other fields in the GLS data could be handy, so makes sense to have a mechanism to access those. However, the kernel *is* performing regular GLS queries anyway, as it needs to monitor link state internally.

So: would it make more sense for the kernel to expose the extended link state fields in the netlink data instead?

And are you typically querying the active channel, or other, inactive ones?

BTW: I don't have an issue with the current implementation, just trying to find the best approach in general 😊

Thanks Jeremy for feedback.
Will be looking into it further.

Hi Andrew,
updated helper function with assert check and resolved other comments.
Regards,
Surendra A.
See below.
